item.title: Single Responsibility Principle (SRP) in Java
item.description:
1. What is the Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)?

Definition: A class (or module, or method) should have only one reason to change.

The Single Responsibility Principle helps developers write cleaner, more testable, and easier-to-maintain code by separating concerns.

It is the first and arguably the most foundational principle in the SOLID family. SRP emphasizes that each software unit (class, method, service, etc.) should be responsible for only one thing ‚Äî and therefore, should change only when that responsibility changes.

item.title: Open/Closed Principle (OCP) in Java
item.description:
1. What is the Open/Closed Principle (OCP)?

Definition: Software entities (classes, modules, functions, etc.) should be open for extension, but closed for modification.

The Open/Closed Principle ensures that you can add new functionality without changing existing code ‚Äî minimizing the risk of breaking something that already works.

This principle is key for:

  • ‚úÖ Minimizing regression bugs
